creator: srimantajana@yahoo.com
text:
Bug 1)  I had used the 

<jsp:useBean id="manageOrg" 
	scope="session"
	class="semantic.manage.ManageOrganization"
/>
<jsp:useBean id="control" 
	scope="page"
	class="semantic.manage.ManageControl"
/>
<jsp:setProperty name="manageOrg" 
	property="Criteria" 
/>
<jsp:setProperty name="manageOrg" 
	property="Operator" 
/>

.....

I am getting compliation error 

Message ' No information about property "Criteria" in bean 
semantic.manage.ManageOrganization"

I had check the class path and if I use

manageOrg.setCriteria("Hello")  in jsp scriplet and

used 

System.out.println(manageOrg.getCriteria());

 I am able to see the value in console.

I found there is a  method < introspecthandler(....) > in the JspRuntime class 
which does not function properly.

This error also available in Tomcat 3.2/3.3 etc

Bug 2)

I had used the 

<jsp:useBean id="manageOrg" 
	scope="session"
	class="semantic.manage.ManageOrganization"
/>
<jsp:useBean id="control" 
	scope="page"
	class="semantic.manage.ManageControl"
/>
<jsp:setProperty name="manageOrg" 
	property="*" 
/>
<jsp:setProperty name="manageOrg" 
	property="*" 
/>

.....


I am not getting compilation error but no value is set for any of the property.

All the get methods in my bean including

System.out.println(manageOrg.getCriteria());

returns null.

I calls intrspect(..) method in JspRuntime class.

I had used jdk 1.3.1 for this testing

creator: craig.mcclanahan@sun.com
text:
JSP expects you to use standard JavaBeans naming conventions for properties.  In
particular, when you refer to the property itself, the first character should be
lower case.  Trye it with:

  <jsp:setProperty name="manageOrg"
               property="criteria"/>

instead.  For more information, see the JavaBeans Specification (version 1.0.1)
available via <http://java.sun.com/products/javabeans>.

I will try with small case and give the feedback soon.

creator: srimantajana@yahoo.com
srimantajana@yahoo.com
text:
I tried with lower case letter as you mentioned and it works for me. It looks 
me tomcat is case sensitive where weblogic works irrespective of case
